------=_NextPart_000_0098_01C9D8C5.7FCD55D0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Colin and the group,
 
I feel like I need to re-think my objectives for HyperNEAT4CUDA.
Originally, my thought was a simple demonstration means of using a factory
class to generate the combined CPU code / GPU kernels using floats for
everything and not worrying about optimizing parallelism issues. My original
hope was to separate the concerns of an experiment for MPP on GPUs and make
the neuro-evolution of the topology and weights easier to understand.
 
This masks many substantive issues that are really just peripherally related
to NEAT, that being optimizing the decomposition and parallelization of
tasks between the CPU cores and the GPU process cores, and how these two
components interact with a partitioning of data. Even simple parallel
programming is non-deterministic. This is interesting, but doesn't belong in
a NEAT forum, so I believe.  
 
Another major piece of the puzzle is just standard graph theory stuff, the
layout of network nodes where both distance and weight are evolved.  I've
been using Graph Drawing with Intelligent Placement (GRIP - see Pavel Gajier
and Steven Kobourov's work at U of Arizona).  This describes the SA and
maximal independent sets necessary to locate large numbers of nodes and
describe the graph thermodynamics.
http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/gajer02grip.html
 
I've found this important to HyperNEAT, others may not.
 
The critical, final piece of the puzzle is the application of Inverse Theory
to Neuro Evolution of Augmenting Topologies.  This is in answer to your
question: "What do you refine towards? e.g. when evolving a
controller with no defined 'correct' output?" For a reachable introduction
to Inverse Theory, see Scales, Smith and Treitel "Introductory Geophysical
Inverse Theory" http://acoustics.mines.edu/~jscales/gp605/snapshot.pdf
 
The problem I have of describing the interrelationship of all the above with
HyperNEAT is "it's all entangled, and interrelated" - meaning it works
precisely like a TWEANN.  I've been working with NEAT devices for over eight
years, Kohonen SOFM before that - and I wish I could more precisely describe
their behavior in deterministic terms.  I can't. I can describe them
mathematically in probabilistic terms, but that isn't very satisfying to
most folks.
 
Ken Lloyd
 
============================
Kenneth A. Lloyd
CEO - Director of Systems Science
Watt Systems Technologies Inc.
Albuquerque, NM USA
 
kenneth.lloyd[at]wattsys.com
kenneth.lloyd[at]incose.org     Research Director - MBSE of Complex,
Adaptive and Stochastic Systems
kenneth.lloyd[at]nmug.net      
 <http://www.wattsys.com/> www.wattsys.com
 
 <http://www.linkedin.com/pub/7/9a/824> http://www.linkedin.com/pub/7/9a/824
 
http://kenscomplex.blogspot.com/

U.S.C. 2510-2521
